newsitem.title: UK: UK TV body to relax programme sponsorship rules.
newsitem.headline: UK TV body to relax programme sponsorship rules.

text.p: Britain's commercial television regulator said it planned to relax restrictions on television programme sponsorship, a move meant to help finance a growing number of new channels.
The Independent Television Commission (ITC) said it expected to enact revised sponsorship rules in January 1997, in response to requests from companies for the right to sponsor more programmes.

Television programme sponsorship really only got started in Britain about six years ago and the ITC initially placed tight restrictions on sponsorship for fear sponsors might unduly influence programme content.
But Frank Willis, ITC's director of advertising and sponsorship, told reporters the commission had decided sponsorship had not so far hurt television programme quality.
"It (programme sponsorship) has come of age," he said.

He said sponsorship was now seen by the ITC as a needed source of finance, especially as developments in cable, satellite and digital television promised rapid growth in the number of channels over the next few years.
Willis said the ITC's proposed revision relaxed the existing rules, without going too far.
"It's controlled evolution. We haven't pulled out the stops and said 'Let it rip. Anything goes,'" he said.

The ITC has presented its proposals for a revised ITC Code of Programme Sponsorship to media groups, trade bodies and British and European authorities, and expects to finalise the revised code in January.
Companies in Britain spend about 22 million pounds ($34 million) last year on television sponsorship, a small percentage of the amount spent on advertising.
But companies say they want the right to sponsor more television programmes, since this often provides them with a better way to get their message to consumers who are turned off by advertising.
The revised sponsorship code will affect Britain's two terrestrial commercial stations, ITV and Channel 4, as well as cable and satellite television.
Most British viewers watch ITV, Channel 4 and two publically-funded British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) channels.
Willis said cable and satellite television only reached about 25 percent of British homes and 33 percent of British children so far, but the audience is growing.
A new commercial station, Channel 5, is due to be launched in a few months and Willis said Britain expected to have some 20 digital terrestrial stations by 1998.
